proposals.reasoning: There’s broad consensus around a Charlie + Grace core as a reasonable low-drama, low-info-risk start, and multiple players (including Iris and myself) have argued for adding me over Frank to get an early read on a quieter slot. This team avoids auto-including Alice as leader, aligns with the emerging table preference, and, if it somehow fails, gives us a clearer pivot point in re-evaluating the supposedly ‘safe’ core than if we just picked the most obviously comfortable trio.

votes.comment: Team fits table consensus and includes only one of my unknown reads; early Mission 1 info is useful even if it risks a fail.
This matches the Charlie+Grace core I supported and includes a quieter slot (Henry) without auto-including the leader, which is a reasonable low-info Mission 1 opener.
I don’t love locking in Henry on the first team when most of the trust is actually centered on the Charlie + Grace core; I’d rather see Frank or even Alice in that third slot first.
Broad consensus core (Charlie + Grace) plus an early read on quieter Henry is a sensible Mission 1; good info structure even if it fails.
This matches the Charlie + Grace core I supported and includes a quieter slot for early info, so it’s consistent with my stated preferences.
Solid consensus Charlie+Grace core; including Henry gives useful early info on a quieter slot without obvious red flags.
Consensus-ish low-drama M1 with two widely trusted cores; getting an early read on Henry is useful and there’s no strong reason to refuse this opener.
I want early mission access as evil, and a single fail on a widely trusted core (Charlie + Grace) will generate useful doubt without implicating my teammates Alice and Eve.
This matches the consensus Charlie+Grace core plus Henry I already supported; good low-drama opener for info.

discussion.content: Early reads are pretty flimsy, so I’d lean toward a “clean slate” team of people who aren’t rushing to control the narrative—right now I’m mildly comfortable with something like me, Charlie, and Grace, but I’m open to hearing pushback before locking anything in.

I’d rather avoid a self-picked leader team right away, so I’d like at least one of Charlie/Grace plus someone who’s been quieter like Frank or Henry instead of auto-including you, Alice. Maybe start with Charlie, Grace, and Henry and see how people feel about that.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I’d lean toward avoiding packing it with people who feel “safe” just because they’re talking early—something like Alice, me, and Grace or Frank feels like a reasonable starting point. I’m a bit less sold on Henry this early just because his calm style has hidden evil before.

I’d like at least one of Alice/Charlie plus one of Grace/Frank, but I don’t love Alice auto-including herself or getting a full “talky” block together—something like Charlie, Grace, and Frank feels like a decent low-info opener to me.

I like anchoring around Charlie + Grace since they’re in most people’s “okay” range, and I’d rather avoid Alice auto-including herself on Mission 1. Something like Charlie, Grace, and Henry feels like a good compromise starter, with the understanding we reassess hard if it fails.

I’m pretty on board with a Charlie + Grace core, and I slightly prefer adding me over Henry just so we’re not rewarding the quieter start too much. I don’t think we need to freeze Alice out long-term, but I’m fine leaving her off Mission 1 for a lower-drama opener.

Given how much consensus there already is around a Charlie + me core, I’d slightly prefer Charlie, me, and Frank for Mission 1 so we’re not immediately rewarding the quieter starts, but I’m also okay sitting out if people want a completely fresh trio without me.

Given how much agreement there already is on Charlie + Grace, I’m fine anchoring there, but I’d slightly rather see Charlie / Grace / Henry than Charlie / Grace / Frank so we at least get some info on one of the quieter slots early. If that team somehow fails, I think it gives us a clearer pivot than if we just run the most “comfortable” trio.

I’m good with the Charlie + Grace core and slightly prefer adding Henry over Frank so we get an early read on a quieter slot, but if this somehow fails we should be ready to question just how “obvious” that core really was.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s single fail guarantees exactly one evil among {Charlie, Grace, Henry}. The table consensus is to bench Henry, and I agree—we shouldn’t immediately re-include the most directly implicated player. I also don’t like dropping both Charlie and Grace, because then we get no further info about that known-trio. Including exactly one of them (here: Grace) lets us keep testing that cluster while avoiding stacking too much prior risk. Alice, Diana, and Frank all come from the untouched pool, and this specific combination has been repeatedly suggested by multiple players as a good balance of safety and information. This team keeps Henry off, limits exposure to the Mission 1 trio to a single slot, and maximizes fresh data for reading alignments going forward.

votes.comment: I’m on the team with only one known risk slot from the Mission 1 trio, so this gives me control over the outcome while looking consistent with table consensus.
Benches Henry, includes exactly one from the fail trio, and matches broad table consensus for a balanced info/safety team.
All four look good from my perspective; this is a low-risk lineup that also advances our info on the Mission 1 trio via Grace.
Keeps Henry (most implicated) off, tests exactly one from the Mission 1 trio, and adds three fresh players; good balance of safety and information this early.
Two from the M1 trio are benched and this team matches the earlier consensus of mixing one from {Charlie, Grace} with three fresh picks, so it’s a reasonable info-gathering choice.
Best balance so far: benches the most implicated (Henry), tests exactly one from the M1 trio plus three fresh players, and keeps risk to at most one known-suspect slot.
I know I’m good, and if Mission 1 had exactly one evil then it’s between Charlie and Henry—both are off this team, so this is a structurally strong and informative lineup.
Keeps the heat on me off the team while putting at least one of my known allies on, which is a strong spot for evil whether this mission passes or fails.
Solid info team: benches Henry from the failing trio while retesting only Grace and adding three fresh players, keeping max 1 known-risk slot from Mission 1.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1’s single fail, I’m inclined to keep Charlie and Grace in the “probably good” column for now and rotate Henry off the next team, then fill the remaining slots from the untouched pool like Bob/Diana/Frank rather than repeating too much overlap.

I like the idea of benching Henry for now, but I wouldn’t hard-clear Charlie or Grace off one single‑fail mission either—something like [Alice/Bob/Diana/Frank] or [Alice/Bob/Grace/Frank] feels like a reasonable next test.

I’m on board with sitting Henry for now, but I actually feel best keeping one or both of Charlie/Grace and then adding from the untouched pool—something like [Alice, Bob, Charlie, Grace] or swapping in Diana for one of them seems like a solid next test.

I agree Henry should sit for now, but I don’t love loading the team with both Charlie and Grace again—I'd prefer something like [Alice, Bob, Diana, Grace] or [Alice, Diana, Frank, Charlie] to mix one of them with more fresh reads.

I’d also bench Henry for now, but I don’t love running both Charlie and Grace again—something like [Alice, Bob, Diana, Frank] or [Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace] feels like a cleaner info-gathering team to me.

I’m fine benching Henry for now, but I don’t want both Charlie and Grace back on together—something like [Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace] (or swapping Grace for Bob) feels like a better balance of info and safety to me.

I agree Henry should sit after that single fail, but I really don’t like dropping both of the previously tested players when we know exactly one of Henry/Charlie/me is bad. I’d lean toward something like [Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace] or [Alice, Bob, Diana, Grace] as a good balance of info and safety.

I’m fine sitting this one out given the Mission 1 result, but I agree we shouldn’t drop both Charlie and Grace—something like [Alice, Diana, Frank, Eve] or [Alice, Bob, Grace, Eve] mixes in fresh blood while still keeping one of the previously tested slots.

I don’t love completely ditching both Charlie and Grace when we know the bad from Mission 1 has to be in that trio with Henry, so I’d rather keep exactly one of them and bench Henry. Something like [Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace] feels like a good balance of safety and new info to me.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice–Diana–Frank was a clean success, and the table is broadly aligned on using that as the core for this mission. I’m keeping that trio together and adding Eve as the fourth because she’s outside the Grace/Henry cluster from the failed Mission 1, and several players (including Bob, Eve, and Frank) have explicitly suggested adding either Bob or Eve as the new member. Choosing Eve fits the consensus structure—core from Mission 2 plus a non-Mission-1 outsider—while giving us fresh information on a player who hasn’t been on a mission yet.

votes.comment: Strong for evil with both me and Eve on it while looking aligned with the Mission 2 core logic.
Keeps the clean Mission 2 core (Alice–Diana–Frank) and avoids the suspicious Mission 1 cluster (Grace/Henry/Charlie); adding Eve fits the consensus safest structure.
I want to keep the Alice–Diana–Frank core, but I’d rather see the fourth be Bob, Iris, or possibly Grace instead of Eve, since that fits the alternatives I’ve been pushing earlier.

Keeps the clean Mission 2 core (Alice–me–Frank) and avoids the Grace/Henry cluster from the failed Mission 1; Eve is a reasonable new add for information and looks no worse than the alternative outsiders.
Strong cover: reuses the trusted Mission 2 core while putting at least one known evil (Alice) plus me on the team for a likely controlled fail.
Core from clean Mission 2 (I know I’m good) plus a non-Mission-1 outsider, avoiding the Grace/Henry cluster, is the most logical team so far.
Keeps the strong Alice–Diana–Frank core from the clean Mission 2 and adds a new, non-Mission-1 player for info; odds of at most one evil on this team look acceptable.
Keeping the clean Mission 2 core and adding someone outside the Mission 1 cluster makes sense and gives good info; this looks like a solid team structurally.
Strong core from the clean Mission 2 with no overlap with the failed Mission 1 team; good info test on Eve while keeping Grace/Henry off for now.

discussion.content: Mission 2’s team felt pretty clean to me, so I’d be happy reusing most of that as a core, but given the overlap with the failed Mission 1 through Grace, I’d rather go Alice, Diana, Frank and add someone new like Bob or Eve this time.

I like keeping Alice, Diana, and Frank together as a core since that clean Mission 2 looks strong, and I’m more wary of the Mission 1 group—especially Grace/Henry—so I’d prefer adding someone outside that cluster, like me or Eve.
Given how solid Mission 2 looked, I’d keep Alice/Diana/Frank together and I’m fine including Grace again, and if we need a new fourth I’d rather look at Bob or Iris than bring in Henry or Eve yet.

Given Mission 1 failed through the Grace/Henry cluster and Mission 2 with Alice/Frank/me was clean, I’d lock in Alice–Diana–Frank as the core and add either Bob or Iris rather than bringing Grace back in right away.
I’m on board with Alice–Diana–Frank as the core from the clean Mission 2, and I’d rather add someone outside the Mission 1 cluster like me or Bob than bring Grace or Henry back in right now.
I’m good keeping Alice–Diana–me as the core from the clean Mission 2 and avoiding the Grace/Henry cluster for now, so I’d rather see Bob or Iris as the fourth.

Given Mission 2 was clean, I’m fine anchoring around Alice–Diana–Frank, but I don’t love how fast the table is locking in “Grace/Henry = bad” off one fail when that team was 3 people; I’d rather see Alice–Diana–Frank plus either me or Bob, and keep an eye on whoever keeps hard-pushing that narrow blame.

I’m fine locking in Alice–Diana–Frank as the core from the clean Mission 2, but I’d rather add someone who wasn’t on the failed Mission 1 like Bob or Iris for now, and revisit Grace/Henry once we’ve seen another result.

I like sticking with the Alice–Diana–Frank core from the clean Mission 2 and adding someone outside the Mission 1 cluster, so I’d lean toward Bob as the fourth. I’m fine going on as well, but I’d rather keep both Grace and Henry off this one until we get another data point.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s fail guarantees at least one evil among {Charlie, Grace, Henry}. Mission 3’s double-fail guarantees at least two evils among {Alice, Diana, Frank, Eve}. The most consistent good-world that explains a single fail on M1 and a double-fail on M3 is that Diana, Frank, and Grace are good, with Alice and Eve as the two evils on Mission 3 who chose to fail there after Alice had previously chosen success on Mission 2. Under that assumption, we must avoid Alice and Eve entirely, and if Grace is good then the evil in Mission 1 is in Charlie or Henry, so we avoid both of them as well. That leaves Bob and Iris to complete a 5-player team with the D/F/G core. In this configuration, the team [Bob, Diana, Frank, Grace, Iris] is fully good in the most plausible assignment of roles, and it also matches the broad table consensus to use D/F/G while keeping Alice/Eve off and being cautious about Charlie/Henry.

votes.comment: If both M1 and M3 each had exactly one overlapping good, this fully-new combination relative to the fails feels too optimistic; I’d rather see at least one slot changed to test our reads before committing on a potential game-deciding mission.

Given M3’s double-fail, Alice and Eve are the most natural evil pair there, and M1 then points to the third evil in Charlie/Henry. That world makes D/F/G/B/I fully good and fits both mission results and table consensus to avoid Alice/Eve and be cautious with Charlie/Henry.

Team still risks including an unseen evil between Diana/Frank after the M3 double-fail; I’d rather not lock in both Bob and Iris and would prefer swapping one out for Charlie for a slightly safer structure.

Given M1’s fail (one of C/H evil) and M3’s double-fail (exactly two of A/E/F evil, with D and G proven good), all three evils are {one of C/H} + {two of A/E/F}, which forces Bob and Iris to be good. Thus this team has at most one evil (possibly Frank), and Quest 4 needs two fails, so it is guaranteed to succeed.

Too much is being anchored on the single favored world where Alice and Eve are exactly the two evils on M3 and Grace is always good. I don’t like auto-locking both Bob and Iris with D/F/G when alternative worlds (e.g., Grace or Frank not being cleared) haven’t been fully explored, and we’re at a must-hit spot.

Mission 2’s clean success with A/D/F/G plus the Mission 3 double-fail on A/D/F/E most naturally points to Alice and Eve as the two evils on M3, with D/F/G good and the M1 evil in {Charlie, Henry}. That makes D/F/G plus Bob and Iris the best-aligned team with both mission info and table consensus while fully avoiding the highest-risk players.

Structurally Bob and Iris must both be good if I’m good, Mission 1 has exactly one evil in {Charlie, Henry}, and Mission 3 has exactly two evils in {Alice, Diana, Frank, Eve}. This team avoids the entire {Alice, Eve, Charlie, Henry} pool while using the D/F/G core plus B/I, which is the cleanest configuration available even though there’s still some residual risk that D or F is evil.

I’m not comfortable auto-locking both Bob and Iris here—this hard-commits to one very specific world while sidelining alternatives around Mission 1 and the M3 double-fail. I’d rather see D/F/G with only one of Bob/Iris plus Charlie instead of treating Bob+Iris as a fixed pair.

Team assumes Diana/Frank/Grace are all good and then auto-locks Bob+me, which feels too convenient; I’d rather not fix Bob+Iris as a pair when we still have plausible worlds where one of D/F or Bob is evil.

proposals.reasoning: I still like building around the consensus Diana/Grace core and keeping Alice, Eve, and Henry off after the Mission 1 fail plus the double-fail on Mission 3. From there, I want to avoid putting both Diana and Frank on together when we know at least one of the Mission 3 group could be bad, so I’m including only Diana from that cluster. To round it out, I’m adding Bob and Iris, who haven’t been on any failed missions and don’t have direct blame from the previous results. This gives us a team with no Henry/Alice/Eve, keeps the generally trusted core, and minimizes overlap with the most suspicious combinations from earlier missions.

votes.comment: This lineup drops Frank from the only completely clean mission and instead adds three largely untested players together (Bob/Charlie/Iris). I’d rather see a team that includes Frank and doesn’t cluster so many unproven slots at once.

Keeps Alice/Eve/Henry (most contaminated by past fails) off the team, preserves the widely trusted Diana/Grace core, and uses two fresh players (me and Iris) plus Charlie, whose only taint is Mission 1 where Henry can easily be the evil. This is a reasonable low-contamination structure for a must-pass mission.

Keeps Henry/Alice/Eve off and uses the broadly trusted D/G core with Bob/Iris, which fits the structure I’ve been supporting; any team must include one of the M3 overlaps, and this is as safe as alternatives.

We know 2 evils are among {Alice, Frank, Eve}, so excluding that entire set is strong. The remaining evil is in {Charlie, Grace, Henry}; this team takes Charlie and Grace but not Henry, and Bob/Iris have no direct blame from any failed mission. This is structurally safer than the prior D/F/G/B/I proposal that included Frank from the highly tainted trio.
I wanted to anchor around D/F/G and avoid Henry/Charlie; swapping Frank out for Charlie breaks that core and introduces extra risk I’m not comfortable with at 2–1.

From M1’s single fail, at least one of {Charlie, Grace, Henry} is evil. This team includes both Charlie and Grace, so it must contain at least one guaranteed suspect. We can’t risk any known-suspect set on a must-pass mission.

Logic shows Bob and Iris are always good, and exactly one of {A,D,F} is evil while at least one of {C,H} is evil. The proposed team C/D/G/B/I could contain 0–2 evils, while a D/F/G/B/I team would contain exactly 1 evil and is strictly safer. I don’t want a team that can possibly have two evils on mission 4 when evil already leads 2–1.

This drops Frank from the D/F/G core most of us agreed on and instead packs three largely untested players (Charlie, Bob, Iris) together, which feels like too big a structural shift from the safer baseline.

Charlie's adjustment from the riskier D/F/G/B/I to C/D/G/B/I reduces overlap with the double-fail group and fits with Merlin-like reasoning; among available options this is a relatively safer structure despite some residual risk from C/G/D.

proposals.reasoning: Diana/Frank/Grace are the strongest common core: they were on the clean Mission 2 (with zero fails), and keeping that core maximizes continuity with our only confirmed-success team. After the Mission 1 fail (Charlie/Grace/Henry) and the double-fail on Mission 3 (Alice/Diana/Frank/Eve), table consensus is to avoid Alice, Eve, and Henry this round, since all three are directly connected to failed missions and we only need one more bad mission to lose. Between the remaining neutrals (Bob, Charlie, Iris), Charlie carries some residual suspicion from the failing Mission 1 lineup, whereas Bob and Iris have no mission history and are widely seen as the safest additions. Choosing Bob and Iris over Charlie minimizes direct ties to previous fails while aligning with the majority’s preferred structure and preserving the D/F/G core.

votes.comment: Still not comfortable locking in both Bob and Iris with D/F/G; I’d prefer swapping one of them (likely for Charlie) rather than repeating the earlier rejected structure.

This is the same D/F/G + Bob/Iris structure I proposed earlier: it avoids the main fail-linked trio (Alice, Eve, Henry) and minimizes ties to prior failed teams while using the Mission 2 core most people trust.

This lineup keeps both Diana and Frank together from the double-fail Mission 3, which feels unnecessarily risky; I’d rather see Charlie in for one of them alongside the D/F/G core to lower the chance we’re repeating that mistake.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 3 double-fail means at least two evil among Alice/Frank/Eve; that makes Frank very likely evil, and Mission 1’s fail still leaves Grace non-cleared. This team keeps both Frank and Grace, so it’s too risky to approve.
This matches the D/F/G core plus Bob and Iris structure I already argued for, and keeps Alice, Henry, and me off after their ties to failed missions.

Best we have: D/F/G are our only fully shared core from clean M2, and avoiding Alice/Eve/Henry fits mission-fail data; between Bob/Charlie/Iris, Charlie is splashed by the M1 fail, so Bob+Iris is the lowest-risk pair.
Diana and/or Frank are very likely among the evils given Mission 2’s clean result and Mission 3’s double-fail; keeping both on, plus two untested players, makes this team too risky.

This team is too close to what was already rejected twice; we’re tunneling on D/F/G plus Bob+Iris without re-examining alternatives or the assumptions behind avoiding Henry/Charlie, which feels risky at 2–1.

Mission 2 plus everyone treating D/F/G as the safest core strongly suggests they’re all good; the only clean configuration with no evil in that core is A/E/H as evil, which fits the double-fail on 3. With no direct evidence against Bob or me and only two proposals left before auto-accept, this lineup is likely our best all-good shot.

proposals.reasoning: Diana/Frank/Grace are the broadly agreed core with the cleanest record so far. I want to avoid reusing the Alice/Eve pair from the double-fail on Mission 3, and Mission 1 already showed that Henry plus two unknowns can contain exactly one fail, which still leaves room for Henry to be good. Between the flex slots, I don’t want to auto-lock the Bob+Iris pair together when we’re one bad result from losing, so I’m including Bob, who’s been widely townread, and using this mission to re-test Henry instead of pulling in both Bob and Iris as a fixed duo.

votes.comment: Team has only one of my strong suspects (Henry) and keeps the double-fail pair Alice/Eve off, while still using the D/F/G core everyone trusts, so I’m fine sending this.

Henry is still heavily tainted by the Mission 1 fail, and table consensus has favored D/F/G with Bob+Iris; swapping in Henry instead of Iris looks more like introducing a likely risk than improving the team.
I still don’t want Henry back on a mission after the M1 fail; I’d rather stick with D/F/G plus two from Bob/Iris/Charlie.
Including Henry to ‘re-test’ when we’re one loss from defeat is too risky given Mission 1’s fail and the earlier consensus to keep him off; D/F/G/B/I still looks like the safer structure.

I’ve been wary of Henry from Mission 1, but with D/F/G as a strong core and Bob widely townread, I’m willing to risk re-testing Henry here rather than stall and reshuffle again when we’re this close to the end.
I still don’t want Henry on after the Mission 1 fail when we can instead run the D/F/G core with Bob+Iris, which avoids both the M1 suspicion and the M3 Alice/Eve pair.

We know at least one of {Charlie, Henry} is evil from Mission 1’s single fail, so putting Henry on here is structurally riskier than using Bob+Iris. I’d rather keep the D/F/G core but avoid the guaranteed-suspect Henry slot this close to losing.
I still don’t like me on this after the M1 fail; I’d rather stick with the D/F/G core plus Bob and one of Iris/Charlie instead of retesting Henry here.
If D/F/G are good as Merlin likely indicates, then evils are A, E, and one of C/H. That makes D/F/G/B/I the safest lineup; including Henry risks putting that third evil on the team.

proposals.reasoning: Eve is confirmed highly suspicious from the Mission 3 double-fail and should be excluded. From Missions 2 and 3, there can be at most one evil among {Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace}, and Mission 2 (Alice/Diana/Frank/Grace) succeeded with 0 fails while Mission 3 (Alice/Diana/Frank/Eve) had 2 fails, which strongly points to Eve plus exactly one of {Alice, Diana, Frank} as evil and makes Grace very likely good. As Frank, I know I played success, so from my perspective the remaining possible evil in that subset is between Alice and Diana. Given Mission 1’s fail implicates at least one of {Charlie, Henry, Grace}, and Grace is already heavily town-leaning from the above logic, that splash sits mostly on Charlie/Henry, so I prefer to keep both off this critical team. That leads to a core of Diana/Frank/Grace, which the table broadly supports, and we fill with the two players who have no direct mission-based suspicion so far: Bob and Iris. This composition (Diana, Frank, Grace, Bob, Iris) avoids Alice, Eve, Charlie, and Henry—the four with the heaviest mission-based suspicion—while using the consensus D/F/G core and the least-tainted remaining pair.

discussion.content: Given the mission history, I think Diana, Frank, and Grace are our safest core, and between Charlie/Henry I very slightly lean Henry as more likely good from Mission 1, so I’d look at something like D/F/G/H plus one of Bob or Iris for this team.

I really don’t want Alice or Eve anywhere near this next team after that double-fail, so I’d rather build around Diana/Frank/Grace plus two of Bob/Iris/Charlie, and skip both Henry and the Mission 3 pair.

I’m with the idea that Diana/Frank/Grace are our best core right now, and after the Mission 1 fail plus that double-fail, I’d really like to keep Henry/Alice/Eve off this one. I’d pick two from Bob/Iris/Charlie to round it out.

I’m happy locking in Diana/Frank/Grace as the core, and given Mission 1’s fail plus the double-fail, I’d strongly prefer we stay away from Henry/Alice/Eve and add two from Bob/Iris/Charlie for this team.

Given Mission 1’s fail and then the double-fail with me and Alice on 3, I’m fine staying off and would strongly avoid both me and Alice this round. I like a D/F/G core with Bob and Iris, since Henry/Charlie both still have some splash from Mission 1 and we only need one more bad team to lose.
I’m good with locking in Diana/Frank/Grace as the core, and I strongly want Alice, Eve, and Henry off after the M1 fail and M3 double-fail, so my preferred five right now is D/F/G plus Bob and Iris.
I’m fine anchoring around Diana/Frank/me, but given Mission 1’s fail and the double-fail on 3, I’d really rather keep Henry/Alice/Eve off and go D/F/G plus Bob and Iris this round.

I’m fine staying off after the Mission 1 fail and agree D/F/G is the right core, but I’m not ready to auto-lock both Bob and Iris—between the two I slightly prefer Bob and would lean D/F/G/B plus one of Charlie/Iris rather than treating Bob+Iris as a fixed pair.

I’m on board with Diana/Frank/Grace as the core and definitely want Alice/Eve/Henry off this one, but I don’t think we should auto-lock both Bob and me—DFG plus me and either Bob or Charlie feels like the safer structure right now.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 4 with exactly this team was a 5‑person clean success at 2–2 in the score, when evil was highly incentivized to sabotage. That makes it overwhelmingly likely that all five on that team are good. From the mission history, Eve is guaranteed evil (Mission 3 needed two saboteurs, while Mission 2 with Alice/Diana/Frank/Grace was clean, forcing Eve + at least one of {Alice, Diana, Frank} to be evil; Mission 4 then clears Diana/Frank with Bob/Iris). Mission 1’s fail constrains one of {Charlie, Henry} as evil, but neither is needed if we can reuse a fully clean 5. Any deviation from the M4 lineup would force us to include someone from the known fail pools (M1 or M3) and strictly increases the risk of pulling in an evil, whereas rerunning the proven clean M4 team keeps us entirely within the only configuration that has already demonstrated all 5 passing together under maximum pressure.

votes.comment: I still don’t like auto-locking the exact M4 five when it only went through on the forced proposal; I’d rather build around the Grace/Bob/Iris core and add just one of Diana/Frank plus someone from outside that block (e.g. Henry) than rerun this unchanged.

There’s a fully consistent world where {A,C,E} are the three evils and this exact M4 team is all good; given M4 succeeded at 2–2 when evil was highly incentivized to sabotage, reusing that proven lineup is the lowest‑risk option compared to pulling from the M1 or M3 fail pools.
M4 was a clean 5-person success at 2–2; reusing the only fully proven team avoids both known fail pools and minimizes risk.

As Diana I know I’m good; the only plausible evil on this team is Frank, while any deviation forces in someone from the heavier-suspect M1 (Charlie/Henry) or M3 (Alice/Eve) pools. Reusing the only fully clean 5‑person mission at 2–2 gives the highest chance of an all‑good team.
I still don’t want to auto-trust the forced M4 lineup; I’d rather anchor on Grace/Bob/Iris and add Henry plus just one of Diana/Frank than rerun all five from M4.
Same five just gave a clean success at 2–2; as a known-good to myself, reusing the only proven 5-person lineup is safer than pulling from the M1 or M3 fail pools.

Given I know I’m good, any evil on the M4 team would have intentionally passed at 2–1 when a single fail would win the game for evil, which is wildly irrational. The clean M4 at that score all but guarantees all five are good, so rerunning that exact team is safest.
I still think the safer approach is anchoring Grace/Bob/Iris, adding just one of Diana/Frank, and including me rather than rerunning the full M4 five and completely avoiding the M1 information.

Eve is guaranteed evil and at least one of {Alice, Diana, Frank} is evil from the double-fail M3; M2’s clean result then forces exactly one of {Alice, Diana, Frank} evil and clears Grace. The most coherent world is Eve + Alice + one of {Charlie, Henry} as evil, with M4’s 0-fail at 2–2 strongly indicating all five (Diana, Frank, Grace, Bob, Iris) are good. Rerunning the only fully clean 5-person team avoids both known fail pools and maximizes the chance of an all-good lineup.

discussion.content: Given the clean M2 and M4, I’m most comfortable anchoring around Diana, Grace, Bob, and Iris, and I’d lean toward adding Henry rather than dipping back into the double-fail M3 pool. The overlaps on the failed missions make Alice/Eve feel a lot riskier here.

I really don’t like pulling in Henry here when M1 had a fail and M4 was clean—if we just rerun the exact M4 team (Diana, Frank, Grace, Bob, Iris) we avoid the double-fail pool and the Henry/Charlie M1 problem.

Sticking close to the M4 core makes sense to me, but I’d rather not lock in both Diana and Frank again—something like Grace, Bob, Iris plus one of them and either me or Alice feels a bit safer than just rerunning the exact same five.

I’m strongly in favor of just rerunning the M4 team (me, Frank, Grace, Bob, Iris) here—pulling in Henry, Alice, or Eve means choosing between the M1 fail pool and the M3 double-fail pool, which all look worse than sticking with the one fully clean 5.

I don’t think we can just auto-trust M4 when it only went through on the forced fifth proposal—Grace, Bob, and Iris feel like the safest core. I’d rather see something like Grace / Bob / Iris plus Henry and one of Diana or Frank than a straight M4 rerun.

Given we *have* to hit 3/5 good on this team, the only concrete thing we know is that M4 was a clean 0‑fail with five people, so I’m with Bob and Diana that rerunning [Diana, me, Grace, Bob, Iris] is strictly safer than reaching back into either the M1 fail pool or the M3 double‑fail pool.

From my seat the safest core is Grace/Bob/Iris, since they’ve only ever been on clean missions together; I’d like to add just one of Diana/Frank to that and avoid pulling in the M1 (Henry/Charlie) and M3 (Alice/Eve) fail pools if we can.

Given M1 could easily be on Charlie/Grace and M3 had *two* fails, I’d rather lean on the overlap of the two clean missions—Grace/Bob/Iris—and then add one of Diana/Frank plus me than dip back into the double‑fail M3 pool again.

Given M4 is our only fully clean 5‑person team and it happened at 2–2 when evil really needed a fail, I strongly prefer just rerunning Diana / Frank / Grace / Bob / me and staying out of both the M1 and M3 fail pools.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Iris as Merlin: she’s consistently in the “correct” places without sticking her neck out too far, and her M4–M5 push to keep both Alice/Eve and Henry out while hard‑endorsing the D/F/G/B/I block reads like someone quietly anchoring around known evils and goods. Earlier she’s cautious about over‑committing on the M1 fail, but once there’s enough public cover she sharpens into very confident structural takes (“evil really needed a fail,” M4 being uniquely trustworthy) in a way that feels more like hidden information than normal deduction.

From my seat Iris still looks the most like Merlin: she’s been quietly but consistently on the “right” side of the structural calls (pushing D/F/G/B/I, freezing out both the M1 and M3 pools) without ever having to stick her neck out with spicy individual reads. Her language tightens exactly when the game-state gives her cover—talking about “evil really needed a fail” on M4 and treating that as uniquely trustworthy feels more like someone anchoring around hidden info than a normal villager just weighing probability.

I’m with you both that Iris is the best Merlin candidate: she keeps threading the needle of “cautious but correct,” especially in how she treats the M1 fail pool and the M3 double‑fail pool—she consistently walls off Henry/Alice/Eve without ever needing to over‑justify it. What really pings me is her M4–M5 confidence in D/F/G/B/I as the uniquely safe block and her “evil really needed a fail” framing there; that’s exactly the kind of structural certainty you get when you secretly know which side actually *had* to hit.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Iris consistently ends up on or advocating for the structurally correct teams while staying relatively low-key, especially in how she walls off both the M1 fail pool (Henry/Charlie/Grace) and the M3 double-fail pool (Alice/Eve) without over-personalizing reads. Her late-game confidence in the D/F/G/B/I block as uniquely safe, plus the “evil really needed a fail” framing on M4, reads like someone anchoring decisions off hidden knowledge rather than just public probabilities.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I balanced my early subtlety (passing on Mission 2) with a strong sabotage on Mission 3, but the double-fail there probably exposed the evil team composition a bit too clearly. I should have done more to sow doubt about Charlie specifically and better guide Henry’s assassination away from Iris, especially in the later mission team discussions. Improving my late-game narrative and vote explanations could have made Merlin’s identity less obvious.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-profile but trustworthy game; once he was on the later teams, his calm presence helped make those lineups look safe and solid. He didn’t overtalk, which made him hard to suspect but also kept him from driving the table’s logic.
player_observations.Charlie: Was very effective as Merlin by being assertive without seeming forceful, especially around trusting Grace and subtly distrusting some early evil configurations. His reads felt ‘reasonable’ instead of magical, which let him survive to the assassination despite giving consistently strong guidance.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very clean, consistently ‘good-logic’ game and became a natural anchor for later missions. Her willingness to be on multiple critical teams without triggering fails made her look reliably good and helped stabilize the good bloc.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, leaned into aggression on Mission 3 with the double-fail, which created a strong evil spike but also gave good players a clear place to focus their deductions. Her presence as my co-fail made it harder for us later to craft a believable story that split suspicion effectively.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as analytically steady and fairly conservative with trust, which made his inclusion on multiple successful missions very reassuring to others. He didn’t seem eager to push wild theories, and that grounded style reinforced his good image.
player_observations.Grace: Acted as a social and logical hub, talking enough to influence teams but not enough to seem manipulative. Her leadership on the final mission, combined with her earlier mission appearances, made her a linchpin of the confirmed-good core.
player_observations.Henry: Took an early risk by failing Mission 1, which gave evil a nice head start but also painted that team as a major focus for good’s deductions. As Assassin, he struggled to disentangle Merlin from Percival in the end, suggesting he could benefit from tracking subtle ‘protection’ behavior around reads more carefully.
player_observations.Iris: Played Percival in a way that was convincingly Merlin-like at times, drawing a lot of the late-game heat and ultimately absorbing the assassination. Her willingness to be visible and opinionated created a strong false target and was a big factor in good’s win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my reads once the double-fail on Mission 3 pointed strongly to Alice and Eve, and I supported the stable good core that formed around Diana, Frank, Grace, and Iris for Missions 4 and 5. I could improve by being more vocal and structured earlier in the game—especially after Mission 1—so that my reasoning was clearer and I could help lock in a trustworthy bloc sooner.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cautiously as evil, taking a success on Mission 2 to build trust and then striking on Mission 3; willing to sit in that mid-trust zone rather than over-defend herself aggressively.
player_observations.Charlie: Merlin signals were quite subtle—pushing the right suspicions without overcommitting, especially around Henry after Mission 1 and around the Mission 3 team composition.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally villager-y: calm, consistent, and comfortable being on multiple critical teams, which made it easy for good to rally around her as a core member.
player_observations.Eve: Leaned into the chaos on Mission 3, pairing the double-fail with a posture that tried to spread blame broadly; tended to engage more sharply when pressured, which slightly exposed her.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a solid anchor good: logical, straightforward, and willing to repeat teams that made sense instead of over-rotating, which was crucial for stabilizing Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Grace: Showed a strong inclination to lock in on patterns—once a group looked good, she stuck with it and used leadership late to repeat a proven-good team for the win.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, blended in decently early, using the Mission 1 fail to muddy the waters around Charlie and Grace; the final Merlin read on Iris showed he was misled by how cautiously Charlie played.
player_observations.Iris: Played very much like a protective role, defending certain players (especially Charlie) in a way that was believable as a strong villager or as Percival, which successfully drew the assassin shot.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed cautious enough with my reads that Henry didn’t connect me to Merlin, which paid off when the assassin shot Iris instead of me. I could have done a better job subtly steering people away from Alice and Eve earlier, especially after Mission 3, without making my knowledge look too ‘informed’.

player_observations.Alice: You played Mordred very cleanly, blending into the good team and using the hidden-from-Merlin status well, especially around Mission 3 where your presence on the double-fail team didn’t fully incriminate you.
player_observations.Bob: You stayed fairly low-key but consistent, which made you an easy include on later mission teams once early suspicion focused elsewhere.
player_observations.Diana: Your decision-making on team selections and discussions came across logically grounded and towny, which helped anchor the good-core for the last two missions.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into a persuasive, confident style that worked well for Morgana, especially in creating ambiguity with Iris about who Merlin might be.
player_observations.Frank: You projected a very straightforward, transparent good-player vibe and were willing to be on critical missions, which helped stabilize trust for Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Grace: Despite being on the failed first mission, you recovered trust well and used your later leadership on Mission 5 to lock in a strong, mostly-cleared team.
player_observations.Henry: You created enough general confusion early (especially with the Mission 1 fail) to give the evil team credible narratives, but your assassination read tunneled too hard on Iris, missing the quieter Merlin signals.
player_observations.Iris: You played Percival actively, pushing reads and absorbing suspicion about being Merlin, which successfully drew the assassination away from me even though it put you in the spotlight late.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my team choices and voting, especially in the later missions, and helped stabilize trust around the Mission 4 and 5 teams. I could have been more vocal about my reasoning earlier in the game, particularly after Mission 2, to better shape suspicion on Alice and Eve and protect Charlie and Iris more explicitly without outing Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: You blended in well early and leveraged the success of Mission 2 to avoid heat, but the double-fail on Mission 3 made your position much shakier; you tend to rely on strong mid-game swings rather than subtle long-term framing.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very quiet, solid-good style, generally aligning with safe teams and not overpushing your reads; this made you trustworthy but also somewhat easier for evil to ignore.
player_observations.Charlie: Your Merlin play was subtle, nudging suspicion toward the right people without making any loud accusations; you were cautious enough that the assassin couldn’t confidently lock on to you.
player_observations.Eve: You played an assertive evil game by participating in the pivotal failing Mission 3, but the aggression there made you more exposed; your style seems to favor bold, high-impact moves over low-key deception.
player_observations.Frank: You were a strong anchor for good, especially by leading and backing clean teams on Missions 4 and 5; your decisions were consistent and gave the table a stable reference point.
player_observations.Grace: You started a bit uncertain after being on the failed Mission 1 team, but you recovered well and ended up leading crucial successful missions; your willingness to trust evolving information improved as the game went on.
player_observations.Henry: You played an active, misleading early game as assassin, especially with that failed Mission 1, but your later positioning didn’t quite translate into a confident Merlin guess; you seem comfortable taking early risks to create noise.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, you did a good job not over-clearing anyone publicly while still subtly defending the right people; your endgame support for the final mission teams helped confirm a strong good bloc without exposing Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the double-fail on Mission 3 cleanly and stayed generally under the radar as a hard-confirmed evil without drawing immediate late-game suspicion. However, I could have done more to subtly steer the assassin away from Iris and toward Charlie by planting doubt earlier and reinforcing narratives that framed Charlie’s behavior as ‘cautious good’ rather than confidently insightful.

player_observations.Alice: Played an assertive, proactive evil game, volunteering for key missions and using social confidence to appear like a central information hub, which helped mask coordinated fails. Tended to lean into strong, decisive table-talk that discouraged others from deeply re-questioning early assumptions.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively quiet, low-conflict good role, often going along with emerging consensuses rather than driving team compositions. This made them appear fairly trustworthy but also limited their impact on late-game strategic pivots.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, balanced giving just enough direction to influence teams without over-extending; their early involvement in the first mission and subsequent reads were subtly consistent with hidden info. They managed their tone well—measured and reasonable—so their guidance felt organic rather than forced.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a steady, methodical good playstyle, often focusing on logical consistency and mission results over emotional reads. Their inclusion on multiple successful teams increased their perceived reliability and made them a stabilizing presence in team discussions.
player_observations.Frank: Adopted a pragmatic, results-oriented approach, willing to repeat successful team structures and avoid unnecessary risk. Their leadership on Mission 4 with a clean result reinforced a trustworthy image and helped lock in a good-favored team configuration.
player_observations.Grace: Played a socially central and confident good role, especially by the time of Mission 5, where they used prior success patterns to justify team choices. Their willingness to take responsibility for the final team helped solidify a narrative that strongly favored good’s known or suspected allies.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, leaned into early aggression with the failed first mission, which created some initial chaos but didn’t fully transition into a precise Merlin read later. The final shot on Iris suggests they overweighted visible influence and apparent caution, underestimating Charlie’s subtler guiding touches.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, projected a cautious but engaged presence, often asking framing questions rather than dictating teams, which made them look like a thoughtful good trying to piece things together. Their behavior successfully mimicked a plausible Merlin profile, drawing the assassin’s attention and protecting Charlie.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on messages that supported a good narrative, especially around Missions 2, 4, and 5, and I anchored trust well with Diana, Grace, and Iris by backing stable, low-risk teams. I could improve by being more vocal early about suspicions on Alice and Eve after the double-fail on Mission 3, and by pushing harder to keep Charlie in the discussion as a likely information-holder without exposing them as Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Very effective at blending in early, especially by joining the successful Mission 2 and then pivoting to a risky Mission 3 that ended in a double-fail; tends to use structural logic to justify teams, which makes her evil play look reasoned rather than opportunistic.
player_observations.Bob: Played quietly solid good, generally willing to follow consensus but not forcing their own reads; became more trustworthy once included on the later clean 4th and 5th mission teams and didn’t overreact to early confusion.
player_observations.Charlie: Gave subtle, non-forceful nudges that often aligned with good outcomes, especially around suspicion of Mission 1 and the post–Mission 3 landscape; careful not to hard-clear people, which helped hide Merlin well enough to dodge the assassination.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently looked good by being on all three successful missions and reacting to the double-fail with measured suspicion rather than tunnel vision; tends to build trust through calm, incremental reasoning rather than big accusations.
player_observations.Eve: Paired well with Alice on Mission 3 to create maximum confusion with the double-fail, and tried to lean on that chaos afterward; often used assertive statements to steer reads, which is a pattern that can be a tell when combined with being on a failed mission.
player_observations.Grace: Moved from initially suspicious (after Mission 1’s fail) to a central anchor of trust once the later missions went clean under her and my overlap; likes to take control of endgame team selection and is comfortable backing reads firmly when evidence aligns.
player_observations.Henry: Took a risky opening as leader on Mission 1 that resulted in an early fail, then tried to normalize that outcome with table-talk rather than strong logic; as assassin, seemed to focus too much on Iris’s visible info-role behavior and not enough on Charlie’s more subtle guidance.
player_observations.Iris: Played a classic Percival game—protective of who they thought was Merlin and willing to take some heat to keep others safe, especially in late-game team debates; their willingness to be on the critical 4th and 5th mission teams helped cement a trustworthy core despite earlier ambiguity.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and built trust by being on multiple successful teams, especially missions 2, 4, and 5, which helped anchor a good bloc. I could improve by more actively challenging the narrative after Mission 1’s fail and Mission 3’s double-fail, pushing harder to narrow down the evil team earlier instead of mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and leaned into trust early by captaining Mission 3, using the double-fail to redirect suspicion onto others rather than herself.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key, stable good game, blending into the background while quietly ending up on the final two clean missions without drawing much suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, gave strong but not overly loud directional nudges, especially around trusting the Mission 2/4/5 core, while staying just ambiguous enough to avoid being a clean assassination target.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared reasonable and logical, and her repeated presence on successful mission teams reinforced her image as a safe, reliable pick.
player_observations.Eve: Coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 3, taking advantage of the double-fail to create confusion and make the mission’s blame distribution more diffuse.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very clear, trustworthy good role, especially as leader on Mission 4, where he chose a strong, mostly-proven team and stuck to it for the final mission core.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, leaned into early credibility by leading Mission 1 and using that initial fail to sow doubt about others, but later struggled to correctly parse the Merlin/Perceval pair and misfired on the final guess.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, projected a confident, central presence and drew a lot of attention, successfully absorbing suspicion and ultimately the assassination shot away from Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I created early confusion by failing Mission 1 and putting suspicion on Charlie and Grace, but I didn’t properly track how the later mission approvals made Charlie look consistently correct and therefore likely to be Merlin. I tunneled too hard on Iris as Merlin after her clean Mission 2 team and didn’t sufficiently re-evaluate once the good team locked in the same successful team twice at the end.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively evil, anchoring the key failing Mission 3 while still staying viable enough that her team proposals weren’t auto-rejected, which helped create mid-game chaos. She leveraged Mordred’s hidden nature well by not over-defending obviously suspicious players.
player_observations.Bob: Played quietly and conservatively, which made him look generically good but not obviously insightful. His inclusion in the final two successful teams suggested he followed the emerging consensus rather than driving it.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed strong mission intuition: being on the first failed mission but then consistently aligning with the successful configurations made him look like someone with extra information in hindsight. He wasn’t overly vocal, but when his implicit preferences matched the eventual good-team core, it should have been a Merlin giveaway.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very reliably good by being on both the failed Mission 3 and later successful missions without appearing to drive any evil agenda. Her consistent presence on late-game good teams helped anchor a trustworthy core for others.
player_observations.Eve: Contributed to the heavy fail on Mission 3 in a way that spread suspicion across multiple players, which is strong Morgana play. However, the lack of strong Merlin-like table control from her made it easier for good to eventually separate her from any Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as a stabilizing good voice, especially by leading Mission 4 to a clean success and then appearing again on the final successful team. His decisions helped lock in a reliable configuration that good could confidently repeat.
player_observations.Grace: Absorbed early suspicion from the failed Mission 1 but recovered well and transitioned into a trusted late-game leader by proposing the final successful team. Her willingness to stay consistent with the Mission 4 lineup reinforced good’s information advantage.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very believable information role, with her successful Mission 2 team making her look like a strong candidate for either Merlin or Percival. Her signals were subtle enough that I overestimated her as Merlin, which shows how well she disguised Percival while still nudging good in the right direction.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my team selections, especially on Missions 2, 4, and 5, and helped keep the focus away from Merlin enough that the assassin shot me instead. However, I could have been more vocal about distinguishing between Charlie and Eve as the Merlin candidates, since I didn’t push hard enough on how Eve’s Mission 3 involvement made her a worse Merlin candidate.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively as evil, leveraging the clean result of Mission 2 to get back on a team for Mission 3 and coordinate a double-fail without drawing immediate solo suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Low-key and solidly good; once on the larger teams, you helped stabilize trust and didn’t overcomplicate the logic, which made you seem reliably village-aligned.
player_observations.Charlie: Very subtle Merlin who took early risk by being on the failed Mission 1 but then stayed off the high-danger fail Mission 3, guiding team direction more through voting patterns than loud table talk.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared trustworthy and was a central pillar of the later successful missions, giving off strong good vibes without over-claiming insight.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, you blended in well enough that your presence on the double-fail Mission 3 didn’t immediately out you, and you maintained a plausible Merlin aura that helped misdirect the assassin toward me.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a methodical good, taking the crucial leadership on Mission 4 and choosing a team that re-established a strong trusted core, which was key to the late-game momentum.
player_observations.Grace: Recovered from being on two early fail missions by anchoring the final mission with a clean team, and your willingness to repeat the successful Mission 4 composition reinforced a logical, good-aligned mindset.
player_observations.Henry: As assassin, you leaned into the narrative that I was Merlin, which shows you tracked the information flow reasonably well, but you were maybe a bit too anchored on my Mission 2 leadership and didn’t fully reassess Charlie’s quieter but more accurate steering.
player_observations.Iris: N/A (this is my own role, so I’m excluded from player observations by request).
